com.here.sdk.mapviewlite

Class Camera

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.here.NativeBase
      • com.here.sdk.mapviewlite.Camera

  • public final class Camera
extends NativeBase

    Camera provides means of manipulating the way the map is displayed.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Camera.OrientationUpdate
      Represents camera orientation update as tilt and bearing angles.

    • Method Detail

      • updateCamera

        public void updateCamera(@NonNull
                         CameraUpdate cameraUpdate)

        Updates all camera settings to the ones provided.

        Parameters:
        cameraUpdate -

        New parameters for the camera.

      • getTarget

        @NonNull
public GeoCoordinates getTarget()

        Gets the last known target coordinates. The returned value is always within the currently specified limits.

        Returns:

        Last known target coordinates within specified limits.

      • setTarget

        public void setTarget(@NonNull
                      GeoCoordinates targetCoordinates)

        Sets where the camera looks at and triggers a redraw. All the camera manipulations occur around this point. If the coordinates lay outside the target area specified by the CameraLimits, then the value will be clipped to fit within that area.

        Parameters:
        targetCoordinates -

        Coordinates for a target point to look at.

      • getTilt

        public double getTilt()

        Gets last known tilt angle, clipped to currently set camera limits. Initial value is 0 degrees from the nadir direction at the target point, meaning a top-down view of the map.

        Returns:

        Angle in degrees, 0 is looking straight down and 90 is looking along the ground.

      • setTilt

        public void setTilt(double degreesFromNadir)

        Sets the angle at which the camera will look at the target point. Tilt is specified in degrees from the nadir direction, which means that 0 degrees is looking at the map from the top straight down. If the specified tilt value lays outside the limits set in CameraLimits, the value will be clipped to fit within the allowed range.

        Parameters:
        degreesFromNadir -

        Tilt angle in degrees from the nadir direction at the target point.

      • getBearing

        public double getBearing()

        Gets last known bearing, clipped to currently set camera limits. Bearing is specified in degrees from north, clockwise.

        Returns:

        Bearing angle in degrees from north, clockwise.

      • setBearing

        public void setBearing(double degreesClockwiseFromNorth)

        Sets the upward direction of the map. Bearing is an angle specified in degrees from the north in a clockwise manner that will rotate the map counter-clockwise. For example, a bearing of 90 degrees will result in a map where the upward direction points to the east. By default, the map is oriented north-up, which equals a bearing of 0 degrees. If the specified bearing value lies outside the limits set in CameraLimits, the value will be clamped to fit within the allowed range.

        Parameters:
        degreesClockwiseFromNorth -

        Bearing angle in degrees from north, clockwise.

      • getZoomLevel

        public double getZoomLevel()

        Gets last set zoom level, clipped to current camera limits.

        Returns:

        Zoom level, clipped to current camera limits.

      • setZoomLevel

        public void setZoomLevel(double zoomLevel)

        Sets the zoom level of the map. The value will be clipped to currently set limits.

        Parameters:
        zoomLevel -

        The zoom level to set.

      • orbitBy

        public void orbitBy(@NonNull
                    Camera.OrientationUpdate delta,
                    @NonNull
                    Point2D origin)

        Orbits the camera around a specified view point by increasing its tilt and bearing by specified delta values. If bearing should be set to a new value, use Camera.setBearing(double) instead. If tilt should be set to a new value, use Camera.setTilt(double) instead. The method respects currently set camera limits.

        Parameters:
        delta -

        Camera orientation change, containing tilt and bearing angle deltas. Positive tilt angle values increase total tilt, negative values decrease total tilt. Positive bearing angle values decrease total bearing, negative values increase total bearing. To omit updating a specific angle, specify null for it instead of a value.

        origin -

        Point in view coordinates in pixels around which rotation occurs.

      • zoomBy

        public void zoomBy(double factor,
                   @NonNull
                   Point2D origin)

        Zooms in or out around a specified view point by a specified factor. This effectively changes distance from camera to target. The method respects currently set camera limits.

        Parameters:
        factor -

        The zoom scaling factor. Values above 1.0 will zoom in and values below out. Since a distance on the screen is in a linear scale and the zoom level is in a logarithmic scale, the effective zoom level changes by a value of log2(factor). So, for example, zooming by a factor of 2.0 zooms the map in twice, which has the same effect as increasing the zoom level by value of 1.0. A factor of 0.5 zooms the map out twice, likewise decreasing the zoom level by 1.0.

        origin -

        Point in view coordinates in pixels around which zooming occurs.

      • addObserver

        public void addObserver(@NonNull
                        CameraObserver observer)

        Adds an observer to this camera that will be notified on the main thread every time map is redrawn with new camera parameters. Adding the same observer multiple times has no effect.

        Parameters:
        observer -

        The observer to add.

      • removeObserver

        public void removeObserver(@NonNull
                           CameraObserver observer)

        Removes observer from the camera. Trying to remove an observer that is not currently registered has no effect.

        Parameters:
        observer -

        The observer to remove.

      • geoToViewCoordinates

        @NonNull
public Point2D geoToViewCoordinates(@NonNull
                                             GeoCoordinates geoCoordinates)

        Converts geographic coordinates to view coordinates. The result might be outside the view (ie. not visible).

        Parameters:
        geoCoordinates -

        The geographic coordinates to convert from.

        Returns:

        Point in view coordinates in pixels.

      • viewToGeoCoordinates

        @NonNull
public GeoCoordinates viewToGeoCoordinates(@NonNull
                                                    Point2D viewCoordinates)

        Converts view coordinates to geographic coordinates. If the view coordinates specify a point above a horizon, then the result is a point on the horizon drawn below the specified view coordinates.

        Parameters:
        viewCoordinates -

        Point in view coordinates in pixels.

        Returns:

        Geographic coordinates that are displayed under the specified point inside the view.

      • calculateEnclosingCameraUpdate

        @NonNull
public CameraUpdate calculateEnclosingCameraUpdate(@NonNull
                                                            GeoBox boundingRect,
                                                            @Nullable
                                                            Padding padding)

        Calculates camera update needed to show the specified geo bounding rect in its entirety. Clamps the camera update if the provided bounding rect is out of the camera limits. Optional padding can be provided to indicate how much free space should be between the bounding rect and the edges of the view.

        Parameters:
        boundingRect -

        The enclosing bounding rect.

        padding -

        Padding in pixels that needs to be applied to the bounding rect. If the padding is negative or if it is more than the screen dimensions, then it will be ignored.

        Returns:

        The resulting camera update instance.

      • calculateEnclosingBoundingRect

        @NonNull
public GeoBox calculateEnclosingBoundingRect(@NonNull
                                                      GeoCoordinates cameraTarget,
                                                      double zoomLevel)

        Calculates geo bounding rect enclosing camera view for given position and zoom level.

        Parameters:
        cameraTarget -

        Expected camera target.

        zoomLevel -

        Desired zoom level.

        Returns:

        The bounding rectangle enclosing area displayed at a given camera target and zoom level.

      • getLimits

        @NonNull
public CameraLimits getLimits()

        Gets a CameraLimits instance that specifies the current limits for the camera settings.

      • getTargetAnchorPoint

        @NonNull
public Anchor2D getTargetAnchorPoint()

        Gets the point that determines where the target is placed within the view. By default, it is placed in the centre of the view.

      • setTargetAnchorPoint

        public void setTargetAnchorPoint(@NonNull
                                 Anchor2D value)

        Sets the point that determines where the target is placed within the view. Updates the target coordinates according to the new anchor.

        Parameters:
        value -

        Determines where the target is placed within the view. By default, it is placed in the centre of the view.

      • getBoundingBox

        @NonNull
public GeoBox getBoundingBox()

        Gets the currently visible map area encompassed in a GeoBox.

        Note that a bounding box is always rectangular, and its sides are always parallel to latitude and longitude. If the camera is rotated the returned bounding box will be a circumscribed rectangle that is larger than the visible map area. Similarly, when the map is tilted (for example, if the map is tilted by 45 degrees), the visible map area represents a trapezoidal area in the world. Resulting value will then be a larger circumscribed rectangle that contains this trapezoid area. Because of this, corners of the resulting bounding box may be located outside of currently visible area.
